qas.question: What is a requirement for being considered a member of Jehovah's Witnesses?
What aren't considered valid when performed by other denominations?
What do Witness publications say baptism symbolizes a person's personal dedication to?
Jehovah Witnesses' literature puts emphasis on the obedience to not only Jehovah but also to his what?
Individuals must remain Jehovah Witnesses if they wish to receive what from God?
At what age does a Jehovah's Witness do baptism?
What is the name of one of the Jehovah's Witnesses publications?

plausible_answers.text: to be obedient and loyal to Jehovah

qas.question: What do people undergoing baptism affirm privately?
Will an unbaptized infant survive or not if a sudden Armageddon were to occur?

context: <a0_0>Baptism<a0_0/> is a requirement for being considered a member of Jehovah's Witnesses. Jehovah's Witnesses do not practice <b5_0>infant<b5_0/> baptism, and <a1_0>previous baptisms<a1_0/> performed by other denominations are not considered valid. Individuals undergoing baptism must affirm publicly that dedication and baptism identify them "as one of Jehovah's Witnesses in association with God's spirit-directed organization," though Witness publications say baptism symbolizes personal dedication to <a2_0>God<a2_0/> and not "to a man, work or organization." Their literature emphasizes the need for members <b7_0>to be obedient and loyal to Jehovah<b7_0/> and to "his <a3_0>organization<a3_0/>,"[note 2] stating that individuals must remain part of it to receive God's <a4_0>favor<a4_0/> and to <b8_0>survive<b8_0/> <b6_0>Armageddon<b6_0/>.
